Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: What sustainable or environmental practices have been implemented?
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result:
Throughout the provided information, several sustainable or environmental practices have been mentioned or implied. Some examples include:

1. Green Friday - A platform that allows retailers to showcase their sustainable products, emphasizing the importance of small steps toward sustainability rather than expecting complete commitment from brands.
2. Afends - The innovative fashion and culture brand plans to grow their own hemp to use in their apparel manufacturing, demonstrating a focus on using sustainable materials in their production process.
3. Fast Furniture Leader - Committed to using only renewable and recyclable materials, working to reduce their overall footprint by 70 per product. They also offer a pre-loved furniture program, giving second life to previously owned items.
4. IKEA - Implementing sustainable practices such as using renewable and recyclable materials, as well as their pre-loved furniture offering, which helps reduce waste and promote circular economy principles.
5. Fashion Industry - With growing awareness of the negative environmental impacts of the fashion industry, many brands are adopting more sustainable practices, including using eco-friendly materials, reducing waste, and implementing fair labor standards.

source.content: – research products materials processes and regulations That' s why Green Friday was created – it’s a supportive platform to prove that when it comes to sustainability we don't need brands to be all in or not at all And we don't need thousands of brands being  sustainable All we need is millions to be imperfectly sustainable This platform allows retailers to display their sustainable products all in one place – and it’s worthwhile noting nearly all participating Green Friday brands won't be  sustainable however they will all have sustainable deals and offers aka the platform isn’t about judging the sustainability journey of retailers instead it celebrates any and all efforts and gives the customer the choice to shop who they want and how they want based on what is important to themSome of the big-name brands already involved in Green Friday are Flora  Fauna Nourished Life Frank Green ReleaseIt and GlamCorner Want to get involved Contact Green Friday here

Sustainability & Environmental Practices.question: Are there any events or initiatives focused on environmental conservation? If yet then list 10 such events.
Sustainability & Environmental Practices.result: There are numerous events and initiatives focused on environmental conservation. However, providing a comprehensive list of 10 such events might not be feasible due to time constraints and potential limitations in knowledge. Some notable examples include Earth Day (April 22), World Environment Day (June 5th), United Nations Climate Change Conferences, COP26 (November/December 22), Global Climate Strike, National Geographic Society's Planet or Plastics Challenge, World Wildlife Fund's Earth Hour, and many more. These events aim to raise awareness, promote solutions, and inspire action towards protecting our planet and its resources.

They mention donating funds to racial justice organizations and black-owned businesses, which demonstrates a dedication to social responsibility. Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.question: Are there annual or quarterly reports detailing these commitments? If yes, then summarize.
Corporate Responsibility & Commitments.result: Yes, there are annual and quarterly reports that detail these commitments. These reports typically cover the company's financial performance, operations, and strategies. They often mention the efforts made towards channel optimization, flexible spaces, and maintaining strong relationships with retailers and mall owners. Additionally, companies discuss their data protection policies and practices, as well as their compliance with applicable laws and regulations. Overall, these reports serve as a comprehensive overview of a company's progress and initiatives throughout the year.

source.content: channel We expect to see a lot more of these next year as the ROI on a physical store becomes harder to justify in some categories without it being a marketing expense  has also been the year of retailer v mall owner If feels like there hasn’t been a major speciality retailer’s annual report which hasn’t mentioned that it will be looking at store closures or a ‘channel optimisation project’ code for closing stores There’s also been lots of chat in these reports around flexibility to move almost like it’s a ‘flex’ For example in Premier Investments Annual Report they stated that 70 of their  stores leases were expiring in  or were in holdover; or Mosaic with  stores who stated that 41 of their leases would expire by December  or were in holdover and 87 due to expire within the next 2 years So shots were fired from retailers to landlords making it clear that store closures were a likely prospect coming up unless an equitable partnership would be reached With all that said this is what

source.content: support by releasing a range of Pride intimates that cater to all identifications Additionally they donate 10 of profits from this range to The Equality Project an organisation that supports LGBTQI+ communities These examples show that companies can celebrate Pride Month while also making a positive impact on the community by providing financial support to advocacy groups In conclusion while it's essential to celebrate and support the LGBTQI+ community during Pride Month and Mardi Gras companies should be careful not to use these events as an opportunity to make a quick profit As consumers are becoming more aware of the practice of rainbow washing and are seeking out retailers that genuinely support the LGBTQI+ community in tangible ways

greater equality even if it means taking some steps which feel outside of the status quo something Richard Branson raised at the NRF a couple of years ago  A great example of how intentions mismatch action was on display at the NRF though don’t think this is an exception to the rule The NRF have been promoting women in leadership over this conference and running a women’s lounge which I still find a weird concept; yet when it came down to their own action they promoted another ‘white male’ to their board this year Added to that they have no female representation on their board leadership team and only 6 women out of 30 positions on their exec committee Arguable typical of the ‘average retailer’ but when we add in the context that we’re in a society where there are more women than men in workforce…things start to look even more inequitable Where this topic got really interesting was actually in the subsequent session with Kara Swisher Co-founder of Re-Code and Paul Ryan Former Speaker

motivated to reinvigorate their living spaces This has reignited interest in more ‘traditional’ homemaker activities including cooking knitting gardening etc 28 of consumers invested in amenities such as home theatres gyms or studios to make the lockdowns bearable and more than 30 plan to continue spending on their homes post-pandemic as flexible work arrangements become a way of the future post-lockdown As consumers have been forced into lockdown digital connection has become a replacement for many face-to-face interactions Now help is available in virtual form via Zoom FaceTime etc This has forced consumers to realise the value in connection with their local community Indeed 80 of consumers feel more or as connected to their communities and 88 expect these connections to stay long after the virus is contained

have become an important outlet for many of us With this increased need for escapism we have seen a greater interest in entertainment gaming and other ‘time fillers’ As consumers were forced to spend a significant amount of time at home and often alone this shift was accelerated Although Australia and many other parts of the world are slowly opening back up and rethinking a covid-zero approach 94 of people who started a new hobby during the pandemic reported having kept it up Covid-19 has forced us to have a greater awareness of personal hygiene as a means to stay safe There is an unprecedented alertness around proximity and contact with other people with 75 of consumers now sanitising their hands more frequently compared to pre-pandemic Spending nearly all our time at home consumers were motivated to reinvigorate their living spaces This has reignited interest in more ‘traditional’ homemaker activities including cooking knitting gardening etc 28 of consumers invested in amenities

Commerce & Products.question: What products, services, or technologies are available?
Commerce & Products.result:
Based on the provided information, here are some products, services, or technologies mentioned:

1. NutriSource Direct - A US-based subscription service offering personalized dog food subscription plans.
2. My Vitamin Packs - A direct-to-consumer subscription service creating personalized vitamin packs based on an online survey.
3. Function of Beauty - A start-up providing customizable shampoo and conditioner based on individual hair needs and preferences.

source.content: to work out how to use this new tech to add real value to customers Global Head of Client Solutions at Reddit Neal Hubman said that retailers were still trying to understand this new technology “You don’t need to understand the technology behind it rather understand the shift in consumer mindset It’s simply about the ability for digital ownership a decentralised model of the internet and giving consumers greater control over their privacy” He went onto say that “ will be the year of retailers figuring out Web 30 The consumer doesn’t care about the jargon so speak to them like a human” Coming into ’23 firstly we need to stop thinking of this as the post-COVID world There’s still a significant amount of uncertainty and change facing retailers CEO of Kroger Rodney McMullen said it best “COVID accelerated 3 years of growth into about 3 weeks This accelerated rate of change is not yet over We’re still seeing our customer change daily” Tech and data are still as importance as ever but

In  we attended the ShopTalk Conference in Las Vegas which is retail’s premier technology and digital retail conference During our time there we saw lots of cool tech trends and more You can read out our key insights in this presentation Enjoy

dog food service – What a mouthful And to top it off it’s tested on humans With reviews from the likes of Fast Company Vogue  Forbes this US based subscription is sure to shake up the pet food industry Here’s one I’m already on board with – My Vitamin Packs This direct to consumer subscription service creates personalised vitamins packs based on an online survey Each box comes with your name on it and inside are daily packs with a little description They have vitamins to target every need – diet/weight-loss gut health vitamins specifically for athletes immunity boosting vitamins vitamins to assist with conceiving pre  post-natal vitamins…the list goes on Now this one is a game-changer Meet Function of Beauty Just like My Vitamin Packs you take a survey about your hair what your needs/wants are and what colour and fragrance you’d like your shampoo  conditioner to be – you can even name the bottlesIt’s important to note that Function of Beauty is Paraben and sulphate free cruelty free

Commerce & Products.question: What are the key partnerships or collaborations related to commerce?
Commerce & Products.result:
There are several notable partnerships and collaborations related to commerce across various industries. Some of them include:

1. Nordstrom Local and Rent the Runway: Nordstrom opened "Local" stores where customers can return Rent the Runway rental items without paying shipping fees. This partnership allows both companies to reach new audiences and expand their customer base.
2. Kroger and Walgreens: Kroger and Walgreens formed a strategic alliance, enabling Kroger to open "Kroger Express" stores offering fresh groceries and household essentials inside select Walgreens locations. Meanwhile, Walgreen

source.content: We love that by joining forces where the “little guy” is educating the “big guy” we see a partnership where everyone wins – a breaking down of traditional Capitalist rules A couple of examples of brands we love who are joining forces are… Nordstrom Local and Rent the Runway Customers can now return their RTR fashion rentals to the self-service kiosks located within the Nordstrom Local stores – no more shipping fees for customers and a chance to expose new customers to the Nordstrom brand…a true win-win Kroger and Walgreens This winning strategic collaboration saw Kroger open their Kroger Express stores which offered fresh frozen and non-perishable items inside of select Walgreens stores while Walgreens-branded health and beauty products appeared in select Kroger stores allowing both brands to potentially expand market share Adidas and Parley Ocean Plastic Made from entirely recycled material designed to keep plastic out of the oceans Adidas and Parley designed and created a line of

positive effect brand partnerships are having on retail businesses Let’s talk about change and it’s inevitability We live in a world where change is the only consistent thing and yet we operate like nothing will In this article we talk about the modern applicability of Ted Levitt’s iconic ‘Marketing Myopia’ article from Harvard Business Review in the s and how it applies today It’s time to discuss beauty brands becoming responsible for their ingredients - let’s talk clean beauty Beauty giants Ulta Beauty and Sephora now stepping up to the plate with assistance from Annie Jackson Co-Founder and COO of Credo Beauty Let’s talk about Walmart’s Answer to Amazon Walmart Plus A new subscription service which is essentially a mimic of the Prime offer That said we believe there is plenty to learn here Let’s talk about the boycott of Facebook from large advertisers Let’s talk about fashion and the shift by luxury brands towards seasonless sustainability It all depends on you and your

to potentially expand market share Adidas and Parley Ocean Plastic Made from entirely recycled material designed to keep plastic out of the oceans Adidas and Parley designed and created a line of training shoes and other products drink bottles etc Whilst maintaining their mission and culture these brands show us it is possible to partner up and boost your brand value Adidas has seen a boost in brand value of more than 50 since launching the partnership SONOS and IKEA Together SONOS and IKEA have built “The best sounding lamp in the world – the SYMFONISK” These WiFi speaker lamps show the brands combining their expertise one sound the other furnishings to create a product for the everyday home We like this partnership as SONOS becomes more accessible through IKEA and IKEA gets “smart home” credibility through SONOS It’s clear to me that partnerships are the future of retail - they’re the springboard to new customers the leg up to opportunity and exposure and the ability to become more

to see the broader category they are in  The second question to ask yourself once you have an idea of the first answer is ‘What is the great business no one is building’  I remember a couple of years ago listening to the CEO of a large sports business say that he wasn’t worried about his current competition but rather the competition that didn’t exist yet When we look deeper at this the only reason that new competition can come about is that there is space This space is created by a mixture of a businesses myopic thinking; and the customers inherent dissatisfaction with the current offerings in the market All it takes is something to disrupt this unfulfilling relationship I want to mention here that the ‘customer’ can also be a business For example Simon’s Malls in the US who like every other shopping centre operator is under pressure as retailers start closing stores - either because they are restructuring their network or they have moved into administration just look at Neiman

Employment & Opportunities.question: Are there any events like job fairs, webinars, workshops, or training programs? If yes, list them.
Employment & Opportunities.result:
Yes, there are various events related to job opportunities, professional development, and industry knowledge. Some of these include:

Job Fairs:

1. Retail Global Job Fair (online) - A virtual event connecting international retail talent with global employers.
Link: [Retail Global Job Fair](https://www.retailglobaljobfair.com/)

Webinars:

1. NRF Webinar Series - The National Retail Federation offers a series of webinars covering topics such as store operations, supply chain management, and HR.
Link: [NRF Webinars](https://nrf.com/resources/webinars)

Workshops and Training Programs:

1. NRF Foundation Programs - The NRF Foundation provides education and training programs for retail employees, including the Certified Retail Operations Professional (C-ROP) certification.
Link: [NRF Foundation Programs](https://nrffoundation.org/programs)

source.content: In need of an experienced workshop facilitator or Keynote speaker look no further Outside of our own business and brand workshops we are frequently called upon by retailers equity players and businesses alike to facilitate or be a keynote speaker for their offsite meetings and strategy days With our extensive retail experience and sharp consumer perspective we bring an objective and focused energy to every workshop we facilitate We understand that workshops are as much about the people as it is about the output and so have a strong understanding of group dynamics Something we work to pull out during the workshop in order to improve what is created If you’re looking for an experienced facilitator for your next workshop why not drop us a line and we can have a chat to see if we’re the right fit for each other Send us an email give us call or fill in the form and we’ll be in contact ASAP

a way to kick start the tourThis two week intensive educational tour is your exclusive access to best practice retail in the company of likeminded retail professionals Wednesday 11th January Depart AustraliaThursday 12th  Friday 13th January Seattle Retail TourSunday 15th to Tuesday 17th NRF's BIG ShowTuesday 17th to Thursday 19th NYC Retail TourFriday 20th to Sunday 22nd LA Retail TourMonday 23rd January Depart the US Spaces are strictly limited to 10 senior retail professionals and with just a few spots remaining we expect these to fill quickly Registrations will close by Monday the 14th of November To receive the tour information pack or to lock in your spot please or email us here

Join the RetailOasis US Retail Study Tour for  to NYC where we meet with Retail Executives from the world's most successful retail and technology brands and concepts + attend the NRF’s Annual Big Show

source.content: to include in a database compiled by us or our third party service providers for use in direct marketing of promotions products and services; to monitor or improve the quality and standard of services that we provide; to consider any concerns or complaints made against us; and By agreeing to accept the terms of this privacy policy and in providing personal information to us you are taken to have consented or obtained the necessary consent to have personal information used or disclosed for the above purposes At the time that we collect personal information we will make it clear why we are collecting personal information We will not use personal information for any other purpose without consent or where we do use information for another purpose it will either be for a purpose which we believe is related to the purpose for which it was first provided to us or for a purpose which would be expected We may also provide personal information to third parties as outlined below Other than the

including to assist us to run our business and to improve our services and performance including staff training accounting risk management record keeping archiving systems development developing new products and services and undertaking planning research and statistical analysis; and There is no obligation to provide personal information for use by us but if you do not provide us with the personal information that we require we may not be able to provide the information goods or services that you require The means by which we collect personal information will depend on the nature of the service being provided from our clients who have obtained the express consent of the individual to disclose their personal information to us for its relevant use including for use in our business and to provide our services; from publically available sources for example the electoral role the telephone directory or from other websites; or We will always collect personal information directly from the

menus created in conjunction with dieticians chefs and fitness professionals where food is served in biodegradable containers with disposable cutlery •           The development and creation of a “Disney App” which allows teams to book all outings make requests order food book extra practice time report health violations links to mental health resources and even details on how players can register to vote in the upcoming election •           An entire NBA branded Barber Shop was built on site in just 12 hours offering players the ability to get a quick chop with one of six specifically chosen barbers from around the US who themselves were asked to say goodbye to their families for what could be months and quarantine upon arrival •           Custom made giant beds were express delivered to the Disney resorts after officials were notified that the current set up wasn’t working for the players given the average heights for an NBA player in the  -  season is 6-foot-6 •           A

of initiatives and incentives Pepsi is offering to employees in a bid to combat the continual tightening of the labour market “When it comes to benefits staff are looking for job flexibility is the new currency” We also heard an amazing talk from leaders within the fast-food industry including Dominos White Castle and Inspire Brands who have such brands as Arby’s Baskin-Robbins and Dunkin’ Donuts They recognised that the biggest challenge of ’23 will be staffing particularly considering the growth of omnichannel and the new 24-hour economy They talked about using tech as a tool to redeploy staff within the business and the cultural shift from being known as FB companies to players within the tech space Travis Freeman Head of Media at Inspire Brands said of shifting the culture within the FB industry “If the FB industry wants to attract the best in tech it needs to create a culture of benefits and flexibility to compete with the likes of Google and Uber” Given the importance of bricks

people from cross-functional divisions  Added to that they built a place for them to work and build – like an incubation lab you would see in Silicon Valley Within this lab they might have  different teams work on a range of different projects The idea is to unleash ideas bottoms up Like I said earlier there is a lot of detail that underpins both these points – things tangible and not so tangible like cultural change commitment and time However underpinning this is a return to humanity when it comes to technology starting not by working out where you can drive profit or create a sexy piece of tech…but rather where can tech make us more human…give us more time back to connect with one another Day 2 raised some big themes and answered one of them There’s still along way to come when we talk about diversity and equality in the workplace The scary thing is the unconscious bias that lies here…that was so very obvious every within the NRF National Retail Federation organisation I’m

varying responses from retailers and to be honest we’re none the wiser But one theme is clear all are approaching the coming year with a degree of caution Liz Ann Sonders chief investment strategist with Charles Schwab summarised it best Firstly we’re not in a post-COVID world yet And she believes we’re already experiencing a recession albeit a unique form of one What we’re currently experiencing is a rolling recession That is as we continue into ’23 expect prolonged pockets of weakness in the economy / retail sectors particularly when it comes to housing tech and goods Whereas we should expect continual growth in others over the next few years namely services In summary expect weakness to roll through certain sectors of the economy and slower overall growth “Whether it’s ultimately declared an official recession is now purely academic” Labour shortages more on this a little later inflation de-globalisation and digitalisation will be major issues continuing to face all retailers over

channel We expect to see a lot more of these next year as the ROI on a physical store becomes harder to justify in some categories without it being a marketing expense  has also been the year of retailer v mall owner If feels like there hasn’t been a major speciality retailer’s annual report which hasn’t mentioned that it will be looking at store closures or a ‘channel optimisation project’ code for closing stores There’s also been lots of chat in these reports around flexibility to move almost like it’s a ‘flex’ For example in Premier Investments Annual Report they stated that 70 of their  stores leases were expiring in  or were in holdover; or Mosaic with  stores who stated that 41 of their leases would expire by December  or were in holdover and 87 due to expire within the next 2 years So shots were fired from retailers to landlords making it clear that store closures were a likely prospect coming up unless an equitable partnership would be reached With all that said this is what

Research & Innovation.question: What are the latest publications, research findings, or introduced technologies?
Research & Innovation.result: Based on the provided information, there isn't any specific publication, research finding, or introduced technology mentioned. However, some general observations and perspectives from various sources have been shared throughout the text. These include quotes from Neal Hubman (Global Head of Client Solutions at Reddit), Rodney McMullen (CEO of Kroger), and references to articles from SMH and 9 News.

source.content: In  we attended the ShopTalk Conference in Las Vegas which is retail’s premier technology and digital retail conference During our time there we saw lots of cool tech trends and more You can read out our key insights in this presentation Enjoy

to work out how to use this new tech to add real value to customers Global Head of Client Solutions at Reddit Neal Hubman said that retailers were still trying to understand this new technology “You don’t need to understand the technology behind it rather understand the shift in consumer mindset It’s simply about the ability for digital ownership a decentralised model of the internet and giving consumers greater control over their privacy” He went onto say that “ will be the year of retailers figuring out Web 30 The consumer doesn’t care about the jargon so speak to them like a human” Coming into ’23 firstly we need to stop thinking of this as the post-COVID world There’s still a significant amount of uncertainty and change facing retailers CEO of Kroger Rodney McMullen said it best “COVID accelerated 3 years of growth into about 3 weeks This accelerated rate of change is not yet over We’re still seeing our customer change daily” Tech and data are still as importance as ever but

in a consistent time rather at times ideas speed up and at other times they slow down This current revolution is bringing us away from the polarity of a male dominated industry and technological rationalism towards equality and human-centred design + technology The NRF is an interesting microcosm of this larger change – showing me that we’re still  not quite there yet…though I’m optimistic In Day 2 we had the emergence of a theme around women in power something that sometimes sits uneasy with me – not the concept of women in power but rather how it’s discussed namely because the larger issue is equality and often these panels don’t address the real matters within it like equal pay and treatment There’s this tap dance around what’s really going on – the more sensitive issues that we experience in the workplace The stuff we women whisper about after hence the Whisper Network – also in reference to the book for those familiar The second presentation of the day was a panel led

In this article that appeared on SMH we discuss rising mortgages and cost of living pressures on lower income households which look set the continue to slow down the sales of big ticket items putting pressure on businesses In this news article from 9 News we talk about the future of shopping and Amazon Go

Research & Innovation.question: Are there any ongoing or upcoming research projects or innovation initiatives? If yes then list them
Research & Innovation.result:
Based on the provided information, it seems like many companies are involved in various research projects and innovation initiatives. However, specific details about these projects were not mentioned for each company. Here is a summary of some notable companies and their areas of focus:

1. Michael Hill - No specific research projects or innovation initiatives were mentioned related to Michael Hill.
2. Funlab - Funlab has a strong focus on growth and innovation with their Chief Growth & Innovation Officer, Blaise Witnish, leading the charge. They likely have ongoing research projects and innovation initiatives to stay ahead in the industry.
3. Releaseit - As co-founders of Releaseit, Peter Krideras and Steve Kulmar are likely driving research projects and innovation initiatives focused on product development and customer experience optimization.
4. Bodd - With co-founders Rob Fisher and Dave McLaughlin at the helm, Bodd is undoubtedly engaged in research projects and innovation initiatives centered around product design, user experience, and sustainability.
5. King Living - Although no specific research projects or innovation initiatives were mentioned regarding King Living, it can be assumed that they are continually exploring ways to improve their products and processes through research and development.
6. Fast - As COO and co-founder of Fast, Greg Schwartz is likely overseeing ongoing research projects and innovation initiatives aimed at optimizing operations, enhancing customer experiences, and developing new technologies.
7. StockX - With a focus on revolutionizing the shopping experience, StockX's co-founders, Ben Edwardson and Josh Luber, are likely driving research projects and innovation initiatives related to data analytics, supply chain management, and e-commerce platform development.
8. Sendle - As the CEO and co-founder of Sendle, James Chin Moody is undoubtedly spearheading ongoing research projects and innovation initiatives to further develop the company's shipping and logistics services, optimize delivery processes, and explore new market opportunities.

While specific project details were not provided for all companies, it is clear that most of these organizations prioritize research and innovation to maintain competitive advantages within their respective industries.

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What organizations, institutions, or entities is the organization collaborating with?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result: Based on the provided information, the organization mentioned two successful collaborations. One is between Nordstrom Local and Rent the Runway, where Rent the Runway customers can return rental items to the self-service kiosks located within Nordstrom Local stores. Another example is the partnership between Kroger and Walgreens, where Kroger Express stores offer fresh, frozen, and non-perishable items inside selected Walgreens stores, while Walgreens-branded health and beauty products appear in select Kroger stores. Both of these collaborative efforts aim to expand market share and provide better services to customers.

source.content: We love that by joining forces where the “little guy” is educating the “big guy” we see a partnership where everyone wins – a breaking down of traditional Capitalist rules A couple of examples of brands we love who are joining forces are… Nordstrom Local and Rent the Runway Customers can now return their RTR fashion rentals to the self-service kiosks located within the Nordstrom Local stores – no more shipping fees for customers and a chance to expose new customers to the Nordstrom brand…a true win-win Kroger and Walgreens This winning strategic collaboration saw Kroger open their Kroger Express stores which offered fresh frozen and non-perishable items inside of select Walgreens stores while Walgreens-branded health and beauty products appeared in select Kroger stores allowing both brands to potentially expand market share Adidas and Parley Ocean Plastic Made from entirely recycled material designed to keep plastic out of the oceans Adidas and Parley designed and created a line of

people from cross-functional divisions  Added to that they built a place for them to work and build – like an incubation lab you would see in Silicon Valley Within this lab they might have  different teams work on a range of different projects The idea is to unleash ideas bottoms up Like I said earlier there is a lot of detail that underpins both these points – things tangible and not so tangible like cultural change commitment and time However underpinning this is a return to humanity when it comes to technology starting not by working out where you can drive profit or create a sexy piece of tech…but rather where can tech make us more human…give us more time back to connect with one another Day 2 raised some big themes and answered one of them There’s still along way to come when we talk about diversity and equality in the workplace The scary thing is the unconscious bias that lies here…that was so very obvious every within the NRF National Retail Federation organisation I’m

someone that understands retail This mixture of understanding desirability as well as feasibility makes us a unique partner Added to that most of the clients we work with on bespoke projects we have long-term relationships with So we must be doing something right We work well together as a team - we’d prefer to be considered a partner rather than a consultant We don’t believe that we can possibly solve a client’s problem alone rather we work best when considered an extension of the business and a group that can help not just bring outside-in thinking but also leverage the thinking of the internal team…think of us as your external in-house strategy team Finally what we often find as a part of our work is that ‘culture eats strategy for breakfast’ Yes the famous Peter Drucker quote turns out to be true time and time again Therefore we make it our priority to get to know you and your team as part of every project we undertake In general the bespoke projects we work on could be broken

credibility through SONOS It’s clear to me that partnerships are the future of retail - they’re the springboard to new customers the leg up to opportunity and exposure and the ability to become more accessible to more people It’s a win-win To listen to the rest of our Podcast with Annie Jackson Credo Beauty click here And coming this week we will be interviewing Laura Beres Director of Corporate Strategy at Ulta Beauty To be notified when this episode airs subscribe here

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: Are there any joint events, projects, or initiatives? If yes then list them.
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Yes, there are several joint events, projects, or initiatives mentioned between various brands and companies. Some notable collaborations include:

1. Nordstrom Local and Rent the Runway: Customers can now return their Rent the Runway fashion rentals to the self-service kiosks located within the Nordstrom Local stores, eliminating shipping fees for customers and providing an opportunity to introduce new customers to the Nordstrom brand (a true "win-win" situation).
2. Kroger and Walgreens: These two companies joined forces through strategic collaboration. Kroger opened Kroger Express stores, offering fresh, frozen, and non-perishable items inside select Walgreens locations. Meanwhile, Walgreens-branded health and beauty products were featured in select Kroger stores, enabling both brands to potentially expand their market share.
3. Adidas and Parley Ocean Plastic: Adidas and Parley designed and created a line of footwear and apparel made entirely from recycled materials, aimed at keeping plastic out of the oceans. This collaboration highlights the importance of sustainability and environmental responsibility.

source.content: We love that by joining forces where the “little guy” is educating the “big guy” we see a partnership where everyone wins – a breaking down of traditional Capitalist rules A couple of examples of brands we love who are joining forces are… Nordstrom Local and Rent the Runway Customers can now return their RTR fashion rentals to the self-service kiosks located within the Nordstrom Local stores – no more shipping fees for customers and a chance to expose new customers to the Nordstrom brand…a true win-win Kroger and Walgreens This winning strategic collaboration saw Kroger open their Kroger Express stores which offered fresh frozen and non-perishable items inside of select Walgreens stores while Walgreens-branded health and beauty products appeared in select Kroger stores allowing both brands to potentially expand market share Adidas and Parley Ocean Plastic Made from entirely recycled material designed to keep plastic out of the oceans Adidas and Parley designed and created a line of

make a change Be the change you wish to see – lead by example show your team your humanity and listen to theirs Be open to criticism and learning and do your best to make a change both personally and organisationally Read – there are endless contributions to this space seek them out and read them some of the things we have read include Rom Watangu The Law of The Land – The Monthly Reni Edo-Lodge Why I’m No Longer Talking to White people about race Watch – so many brilliant films and documentary’s in this space for you and as above last night’s Q+A episode was emotional and raw and a great place to watch and start listening Follow – ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ; ;  Support Retail –  Earth Blended wwwearthblendedcom; Leah Brideson wwwleahbridesonartscomau; Jarin wwwjarinstreetcomau ; Anindilyakwa Arts wwwanindilyakwaartscomau ; Walk About Clothing wwwwalkaboutclothingnetau ; Indii Swimwear wwwindiiswimwearcom; Lianda Swim wwwliandraswimcom ; Jackets with a Voice wwwginnysgirlgangcom; Gilawarra Arts

people from cross-functional divisions  Added to that they built a place for them to work and build – like an incubation lab you would see in Silicon Valley Within this lab they might have  different teams work on a range of different projects The idea is to unleash ideas bottoms up Like I said earlier there is a lot of detail that underpins both these points – things tangible and not so tangible like cultural change commitment and time However underpinning this is a return to humanity when it comes to technology starting not by working out where you can drive profit or create a sexy piece of tech…but rather where can tech make us more human…give us more time back to connect with one another Day 2 raised some big themes and answered one of them There’s still along way to come when we talk about diversity and equality in the workplace The scary thing is the unconscious bias that lies here…that was so very obvious every within the NRF National Retail Federation organisation I’m

Join us as we talk to Daniel Bracken the CEO at Michael Hill Join us as we talk to Blaise Witnish Chief Growth  Innovation Officer at Funlab Join us as we talk to Peter Krideras and Steve Kulmar the Co-Founders of Releaseit Join us as we talk to Rob Fisher + Dave McLaughlin the Co-Founders of Bodd Join us as we talk to Anna Carrabs CEO at King Living Join us as we talk to Domm Holland Co-Founder and CEO at Fast Join us as we talk to Greg Schwartz COO and Co-Founder at StockX Join us as we talk to Robin Marchant Head of Marketing APAC at Shopify Join us as we talk to James Chin Moody the CEO and Co-Founder of Sendle

Collaboration & Partnerships.question: What are the mutual objectives and outcomes expected from these collaborations?
Collaboration & Partnerships.result:
Collaborative efforts between "the little guy" (like Rent the Runway) and "the big guy" (like Nordstrom) aim to achieve several mutual objectives and desired outcomes. These include:

1. Expanding market reach and customer base: By partnering together, both parties can tap into each other's customer bases, increasing visibility and accessibility for each other's products/services.
2. Cost savings and efficiency improvements: Through shared resources, logistics, and operations, both companies can reduce costs and improve overall efficiency.
3. Enhanced product offerings and innovation: Combining expertise and knowledge leads to the development of new and improved products/services, often resulting in increased competitiveness in the market.
4. Building trust and credibility: Joint ventures and partnerships demonstrate a willingness to cooperate and work together, which can enhance the reputation and credibility of both parties.
5. Diversifying revenue streams: Collaborative initiatives can lead to the generation of additional revenue streams through the introduction of new products/services or expansion into new markets.
6. Learning and growth opportunities: Partnering with other organizations provides valuable learning experiences and allows both parties to grow and develop new capabilities.
7. Social responsibility and sustainability: Some collaborations focus on promoting social responsibility and environmental sustainability, helping to foster positive relationships with stakeholders and communities.

out to be true time and time again Therefore we make it our priority to get to know you and your team as part of every project we undertake In general the bespoke projects we work on could be broken down into 3 key areas - inspiration creation and optimisation We work with both retail and non-retail clients across these pillars When you want to know what’s happening around you or the future of a category When you’re ready to create a new strategy or direction within the business When you have an existing strategy but need help refining it and applying it We worked with the team at JayCar to firstly understand their current and emerging customer - as well as the key changes in the category and then we identified what the future of their category could look like On the back of this we developed their experience of the future which involved the creation of ‘Makers Hubs’ A concept now being rolled out We worked with the Mirvac team over a 6 month period to understand the future of retail

values and project consistent messaging  Dom is passionate about data and understanding consumer behaviour Having recently completed a double degree in Law and Media and Communications at Sydney University Dom brings a spirit of curiosity and enquiry to everything she does and is keen to put her analytical and problem-solving skills to use Outside of work Dom enjoys all things sport and is a keen AFL player Dom currently plays in the Women’s Premier Division for the North Shore Bombers
